You can get food at the local bars and restaurants and there's lots to choose from, though prices are usual high for Greek standards overall. Because it get so windy it feels comfortable in the sun and the heat is much more bearable, however that could fool you into staying in the sun longer and getting a sunburn without even feeling/noticing it so do be mindful of that. There's also a platform about 20 meyers from the shore where you can jump into the water from 3 different height levels. reviews.text:
Fourni - a beach where time forgets itself and the sea whispers in stories

Like a hidden treasure chest tucked at the edge of the island, Fourni Beach lies between cliffs and pine trees, far from the noise and haste of the world. This is not just a beach - it's a portal to stillness, a place the soul reaches before the body does.

The path to Fourni winds through fragrant pine forest, as if leading you to a secret shore known only to a lucky few. Then suddenly - the horizon opens, and there it is: a wild, untouched bay, painted by the brushstrokes of wind and sunlight. The sea here is different - deep, rich, indigo blue, as if it has absorbed all the light of the passing day.

The cliffs surrounding the beach stand like ancient guardians, protecting this pocket of peace. The pebbles underfoot are smooth and warm, shaped by centuries of dancing waves. You don't feel like playing music here. You don't speak loudly. You listen to the wind, breathe in salt and pine, and let yourself simply exist.

Fourni is for those who seek not just solitude, but a return to something within. It's easy to imagine ancient gods swimming in these waters, or muses whispering lines of poetry to travelers stunned by the view.

And the sunset - it feels like legend. The sea falls still, the sky turns to watercolor, and everything breathes in harmony - slowly, deeply, lovingly.

The accommodation is situated at one end of a quiet bay, literally 200 meters from the sea, with it's own dedicated spot on the beach with umbrella and sun loungers included (there are two on the beach and two more stored at the accommodation that you can carry down, so four in total).

The beach is a mix of sandy/pebbly, so I recommend you take beach shoes (or you can buy them at the mini-markets there). The water is crystal clear, and like a millpond most of the time!

The accommodation itself was great - it's the bottom floor of a three storey detached property (there was no noise from above!), with two bedrooms - one double (air conditioned), one twin, plus a decent sized bathroom with modern toilet/sink/shower, and an air-conditioned kitchen/dining/living space. (The bedrooms and bathroom look too have been recently modernised - some of the photos on here are clearly old!)

There's a spacious sun terrace at the front, accessed through sliding patio doors from the living area, complete with four chairs and a patio table - it overlooks a 'boardwalk' that runs along the length of the bay - and a small terrace at the rear with a washing machine and drying rack, perfect for drying towels and swimwear.

Parking at the nearby hotel is included, with plenty of spaces, and the host Maria (Stefanos' mother) met us to hand over the keys and give us a quick tour.

There is a restaurant and mini-market three doors down, which was great, and there are more restaurants further along the bay in easy walking distance. All the food we had was great!
